body: IPython and Python versions?
what matplotlib backend is in use?

ups, sorry forgot that.

ipython 1.1.0
python 2.7.3 64 bit

both from the enthought canopy install
backend is MacOSX

Is it slow immediately, or only after you have made your first plot?

Is it slow without `--pylab`?

hm I tried again, but this time it is not a problem anymore. Could it be that mavericks has "learned" how I use python and doesn't cause any lags?

The only thing I have done in the mean while was re-installing the Xcode command line tools which were missing with the new install of Xcode.

Unless someone else also experiences this lag or it comes back, I guess this can be close. Sorry for the trouble.
if it was only once or twice, it could have just been caching various things. Closing.
Also - matplotlib's first run is often quite slow as it waits for a fontconfig call. That may have been it.
ok, good to know. glad it's running smoothly again. thanks anyway!

I think closing was a bit premature before there has been confirmation from others that this problem just goes away by itself.
I for one have the same problem; sluggish under Canopy Version: 1.1.1 (64 bit)
Slow in the notebook to scroll and text select and the command line at the bottom takes ~8 (yes EIGHT) seconds to respond to a <cr>!!
Now running for the second day.
Also looks like USB serial input is timing out after 1 second - but need to confirm that.

I don't think it was premature, since there were no corroborations of the issue. But if you can reproduce the issue reliably in IPython and not in plain Python, with reproduction steps, we can certainly reopen.

This is most  probably due to App Nap, a new feature in OSX that puts unused application to sleep. This can be seen in activity monitor, a column displays whether an app is "napping" or not. If I run plain python, then it never naps, and the prompt stays responsive. If instead I run ipython, then the "kernel" process goes napping after a few seconds, and each time I stop typing for more than a few seconds it becomes unresponsive for a while.
We need to find a way to tell OSX not to do this.

Upon further inspection this happens only when using python with --pylab=qt, while --pylab=osx works flawlessly. To be more specific, in both cases activity reports python being in "appNap" state, but the osx backend isn't bothered, while with the qt backend it keeps freezing. So maybe this is a problem with the qt library?
Sounds like a Qt bug.

As a double check, I installed spyder, which is entirely a qt application and can launch an python interpreter window in a child window. Here there appear to be no freezes anywhere, so not sure what is going on...

It's probably the absence of a window while the Qt event loop is active, so there's no signal to exit napping.

Does it work better when you have a plot window open?

Yes. but it needs to become active. If both terminal running python and the plot window are in inactive, after a certain time app nap puts the kernel to sleep. The following can happen:
1) switch to terminal, which becomes responsive after approx 7 seconds
2) switch to plot window, then to terminal, which becomes responsive right away
3) switch to terminal, start typing, switch to plot window, chars appear right away (basically activating the plot window wakes the kernel earlier)

Try this:

```
defaults write org.python.python NSAppSleepDisabled -bool YES
```

I haven't figured out how to set this on a per-process basis from inside the process (need to figure out how to call `[NSProcessInfo.beginActivityWithOptions NSActivityUserInitiated]` from Python.

For more info on this issue, see [this detailed report](https://support.enthought.com/entries/22861925-OS-X-10-9-Mavericks-Python-Canopy) at Enthought by @jdmarch. It seems like the issue isn't Qt-specific but applies in general to all two-process IPython setups.

I suspect it will also have a real impact on `IPython.parallel`, though that's just a guess right now.

I don't think that is accurate, unless it is something unique to their Pythons - it does not affect the notebook without the Qt backend, nor IPython.parallel.  There are no issues when using the Cocoa ('macosx') backend, nor when working without matplotlib at all.

I am suffering a similar but different problem.  If i have a long-running job (overnight), app nap puts it to sleep.

This is true even after running " defaults write python.python.org NSAppSleepDisabled -bool YES  " before the setting the job going.

I am using the MacOSX backend, with Python 2.7.5, ipython 0.13.2, and matplotlib 1.2.1.

The problem isn't ipython specific, though -- i get the same behaviour running my job in plain python from the command line.
Can you share your script? What Python are you using (not just version, is it the System Python, Python.org, etc.)? Is Qt imported at all?

I've had this issue too, I think I've got round it though. I noticed the nap in the activity monitor too. With Python running in the terminal, locate Python in the activity monitor (which should say Yes in the app nap column) and inspect the process (cmd+i). Go to the 'Open Files and Ports Tab', and one of the list should end in Python.app. Open that folder in terminal, which was in my case:

open /opt/local/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/Resources/

In that folder should be the Python app, right click it and Get info, and there should be a tick box for Prevent App Nap. Check that and it should solve the problem, it hasn't slowed down for me in the past ~2 hours (including a restart).

Tbh I'm very much a novice at this type of thing, so apologies if it doesn't work. For your info:
ipython 1.1.0
python 2.7.5
backend: Qt4Agg
(running ipython --pylab)

Hope this helps.

If it's macports, then it's _not_ python.org - macports compiles its own Python, and I think it might not be a Framework build, which may affect the bundle identifier (I have no idea how that stuff works, or how to get the bundle identifier for a running process).  Can you at least share `sys.modules` when your script starts?

Do you see App Nap if you start a simple Python process that does `while True: time.sleep(1)`?
@minrk what's the best way to share sys.modules ?  simply printing it runs to 2400 lines of text... i assume that that is not very useful?
Would love to hear from @jdmarch, since they do specifically mention notebook issues...
@iamned, you can drop the file into a pastebin and link back here, that will be better than a giga-comment.

@minrk @wms2006 

Having disabled app nap via the finder, in the manner suggested by @wms2006, the problem persists.

I tried running the following code (in ipython):
`while True :
    print time.ctime()
    time.sleep( 10 )`

I went away and had lunch, and the last five outputs i returned to see were:

Tue Oct 29 13:11:44 2013
Tue Oct 29 13:11:54 2013
Tue Oct 29 13:12:04 2013
Tue Oct 29 13:12:39 2013
Tue Oct 29 13:19:15 2013

Obviously, i came back at 13:19, about 6.5 minutes after app nap kicked in. So, boo some more.
@fperez I'm working on getting a Mavericks machine to test on. Everything so far is compiling feedback.
@iamned do you see the same thing with /usr/bin/python?
